awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Biometric Identification Technologies and the Citizenship Document Validation Process
awd_abstract_narration:
In the context of heightened security measures aimed at updating state identification technologies, thousands of U.S. citizens have been asked to prove the validity of their birth. This doctoral dissertation project aims to understand how efforts to update biometric security systems impact the lives of citizens, particularly those living in regions where they frequently must rely on document technology to prove their identity. In addition to furthering the social scientific training of a graduate student in anthropology, this project will generate policy briefs, interactive discussion sessions, a short documentary, and other multimodal work to help inform the public and policy makers about the impact of new forms of biometric technology and governance. This project also broadens the participation of underrepresented groups in science.
 
Through online research, FOIA requests, and semi-structured interviews with state officials, this project investigates what socio-political processes have accelerated new forms of biometric security. Fieldwork includes observational methods at U.S. District Court hearings and participant observation with citizens as they navigate state bureaucracies to establish the veracity of their documents. Other methods include semi-structured interviews with attorneys, judges, advocates and other officials, as well as document, court, and transcript analysis. This research will contribute to an understanding of how new modes of biometric technology and document surveillance help to produce new forms of identity precarity. The research will further theoretical debates concerning the role of documents, technology, and governance in shaping membership boundaries, with an emphasis on understanding what role biopolitical processes such as bureaucratization and surveillance have in social scientific understandings of citizenship.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This ethnographic project examined the growth of identity precarity and insecurity through the interrogation and denial of core state identity documents such as US birth certificates and US passports. The project focused on the experiences of US citizens whose birth registrations federal and state officials have placed in doubt on the grounds that their births may have been fraudulently registered by midwives along the Southeast Texas border. Since the mid-2000s, this has resulted in the systematic denial of thousands of US passports per year to US citizens, especially those whose births were registered in Southeast Texas by Mexican and Mexican American birth attendants. The project examined how broadly and by what processes US birthright citizenship has become vulnerable in the extended US-Mexico borderlands. Through 14 months of ethnographic and digital archival fieldwork, the co-PI tracked how ‘citizens-in-question’ experience and articulate the impact of state identity surveillance, how they experience pursuing or not pursuing legal redress through federal courts, and how they create life worlds despite prolonged bureaucratic suspicion.

Research Outcomes: The co-PI found that while legal citizenship can become unstable for anyone, its instability is mediated by specific configurations of race and nation. Rather than going away, the practice of birth certificate scrutiny has become a routine practice of both the US Department of State (DOS) and the Texas Department of Health and Human Services. The original concern with questionable birth registrations arose out of plea deals that resulted in midwives turning over their entire birth registries, which produced lists of people who were both born in the US and those who were not. This original suspicion has since expanded to include any Mexican Americans who were registered on both sides of the US-Mexico border prior to and event after the establishment of dual citizenship as a legal possibility for Mexican Americans. The project also shows how the bureaucratic suspicion of state identity documents has extended across the last half of the twentieth century. Finally, the research has revealed a legal quandary raised by a 5th Circuit Court of Appeals interpretation of 8 US code 1503 that places a 5 year statute of limitation on anyone seeking to use code 1503 as a way to challenge a denial of a right or benefit of US nationality.

Intellectual Merit: While many scholarly studies of citizenship regard physical birth certificates and passports as relatively stable vehicles for belonging and rights, this study foregrounds how new passport application procedures developed in the post-9/11 US have produced new forms of identity precarity. The project focused on the “fault lines” of citizenship, the places where citizenship, even when seemingly secure, continues to be internally contradictory, unstable, and fundamentally “at risk,” that is, at risk of becoming a site of biometric exclusion and violence (Petryna and Follis 2015; Chavez 2017; Díaz-Barriga and Dorsey 2020). While research on liminal non-citizen statuses has flourished in recent years, this project opens new ground in the study of the ongoing vulnerabilities of and growing challenges to legal citizenship itself: i.e., the use of suspicions of fraud as a way to erode civil rights, the expansion of multi-scalar and transnational security regimes, and the production of new forms of bureaucratic racial exclusion. The project shows how these exclusionary practices can target Latina/o communities while appearing to be technical, precise, color-blind, and dispassionate.

Broader Implications: The project exposes serious vulnerabilities in the protections of US birthright citizenship for those whose citizenship has been questioned by federal or state officials, including a weakness in 8 US code 1503 that may need to be addressed through congressional action. Given the ongoing denial of passports to people with US birth certificates, the project raises the need for the federal government to track and disclose the number of US citizens who have been asked to provide more information after filing a passport application as well as the number of US citizens whose passports are ultimately denied. The project also raises the need for the government to account for the financial costs of defending the Department of State in court cases involving a denial of a right or benefit of US nationality. The role of state governments in destabilizing US birthright citizenship should be further investigated.

Given the confusion created by the original plea deals and the national interest in clarifying state birth registries, the federal government may need to create a legal and humane avenue by which those who are unable to prove the circumstances of their US birth can correct their documentary record or, if unable to do so, apply for permanent residency based on their strong ties to the country in which they have created livelihoods since the time of infancy.

The co-PI is completing a dissertation, preparing research articles, and working with stakeholders to propose policy recommendations.
